Executive Summary



1.1    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The executive summary provides an overview of general facility information generated during the development of the Risk Management Plan (RMP).  Specific information such as storage quantities, hazard assessment data, training dates, Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) dates, etc. is included in the Section 1.22 Audit Report.  This information is updated every three years when Tighe & Bond performs the mandatory RMP audit.  The executive summary also includes the RMP electronic submittal forms.  The RMP electronic submittal form must be re-submitted to the EPA within five years of the initial submission or sooner under the following conditions:



?    No later than three years after a newly regulated substance is first listed by the EPA

?    No later than the date on which a newly regulated substance is first present in an already covered process above a threshold quantity

?    No later than the date on which a regulated substance is first present above a threshold quantity in a new process

?    Within six months of a change that requires a revised PHA

?    Within six months of a change that requires a revised offsite consequence analysis and defined as a decrease/increase to endpoint by a factor or two

?    Within six months of a change that alters the program level that applied to any covered process



NOTE:  If a facility is no longer subject to the regulation, the owner or operator shall re-submit a revised registration to the EPA within six months indicating that the facility is no longer covered.  



Tighe & Bond will notify you at your five anniversary to perform the RMP re-submittal.  In the interim, the Risk Management Program Coordinator or their designees (RMPC) periodically reviews the above criteria to determine if a re-submittal should be made at a shorter time interval.  



The photographs found in the executive summary represent conditions at the time of the initial RMP development.  The Facility should photo-documents cha

nges made at the facility as a result of the PHA recommendations.   The photos include a written description of the specific PHA corrective action.  This information is included in the RMP photograph section.  



1.2    MANAGEMENT SYSTEM

The site specific RMPC has been identified in the executive summary of the RMP.  Please note that the RMPC is a collective term which refers to the overall RMP program manager as well as anyone this individual may designate to assist them with the implementation of this program.

The RMPC reviews the assignments found below with the Facility and assigns responsibilities accordingly.  Management recognizes assigned responsibilities and provides adequate resources to help ensure compliance.



Several positions and responsibilities are identified in this section.  In addition, the tasks are further detailed in each section write-up of this document.  The RMPC assigns general responsibilities as shown in the Section 1.22 Audit Report.



1.3    HAZARD ASSESSMENT

As discussed in Section 1.0 (executive summary) of this RMP, the hazard assessment is periodically reviewed and re-submitted to the EPA as necessary.  This hazard assessment in Section 3 of the RMP also includes maps which delineate the off-site consequence analysis.   This information is provided to the Local or State Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) and the local fire department or HAZMAT response team.   The local agencies should also receive a copy of the emergency response plan and Tier II forms.

The RMP regulation requires facilities to conduct a public meeting on the facility hazard assessment; information released to the public must also be reported to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.  



1.4    PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

Important health and safety information is readily available for the chemical and processes for a variety of reasons (e.g. emergencies, equipment maintenance, etc.).  A significant amount of this information is found primarily throughout the RMP d

ocument.  A separate process safety file is maintained for maintenance information at the Facility.  However, the facility reviews the list found in Section 4.4 of the RMP, as well as the written compliance programs, and provides additional information when necessary (e.g. equipment manuals, inspection records, etc.).  



1.5    PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) has been performed at the facility and is included in Section 5.5 of the RMP.   Appropriate facility employees and outside contractors were involved in this process. 

 

The PHA has identified a number of action items which need to be addressed along with priority codes.  Upon completion of these activities, the corrective actions are documented and the information is filed with the process safety information.  As previously discussed, photo-documentation of corrective actions (when applicable) is included in the Executive Summary.



1.6    OPERATING INSTRUCTIONS

Standard Operating Procedures either existed or were developed for the facility.  These include programs such as lockout/tagout, confined space, hot work permit, chemical procedures, etc.  A number of these programs have standard operating procedures and checklists which are requisite for documenting regulatory compliance, particularly for the regulated process.  The instructions for completion of the forms are included in the RMP document.



For example, the Safe Work Permit Procedure found in Section 6.0 of the RMP is used to ensure that work in the process areas complies with a variety of standard operating procedures.  Whenever work is performed in the process areas, a safe work permit is completed.



The use of other standardized permits/checklists is documented in accordance with the procedures outlined in the programs.  For example, documentation is maintained for procedures such as confined space entry.  As previously discussed, the facility may use the existing forms or substitute an equivalent form.



1.7    TRAINING

Individuals who work on the process at the facility have been provided with specific training on the hazards of the process as well as the safe and proper operating procedures.  Individuals who have been certified in the process are included in the training certification document found in Section 7.0 of this RMP or the Section 1.22 Audit Report.  Any new employees who are expected to operate or work on this process should be first provided with specific operational training and included in the training certification list.

All other affected employees or contractors receive awareness level training in accordance with Section 7.0 of this RMP (e.g. emergency procedures, hazard communications, etc.).



1.8    MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

The facility ensures the integrity of process equipment by determining that the equipment is maintained, designed installed and operating properly.  The primary emphasis behind mechanical integrity is preventative maintenance.  The majority of process equipment has standard operating manuals and maintenance procedures that are kept in the office file.

The facility ensures that recommended maintenance is performed on process equipment in accordance with manufacturer's recommendations.  In addition, modifications to existing systems are performed in accordance with manufacturer's recommendations.  The facility then uses a preventative maintenance file system to update and document compliance.



1.9    MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

The facility establishes and implements written procedures to manage any change to the facility or to the process chemicals (e.g. introduction of new chemicals).  This procedure is implemented by using the Management of Change forms (MOC) found in Section 9.0 of the RMP.



These forms provide a system which evaluates potential changes to the system and potential effects on the process safety operation.  The forms are completed any time there is a change to the process which could affect the overall safety of the chlorine system

.  All RMPC designees are familiar with this process.



1.10    PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW

The facility performs a pre-startup safety review (PSSR) as necessary for new or modified facilities.  The checklist found in Section 5.0 (PHA) of the RMP provides the necessary information to review and evaluate potential modifications to the existing process.  This PSSR process is started as soon as possible in the conceptual design of the project.



If there are any renovations or facility changes which would impact the process systems, it is required that the forms found in Section 10.0 (Action Item Documentation) of the RMP be completed and that any action items be incorporated into the project.  Appropriate changes may also be necessary in standard operating procedures (e.g. lockout/tagout, emergency plan, operating procedures, etc.).  These can be made through Section 9 (Management of Change Procedures) of the RMP.



1.11    COMPLIANCE AUDITS

Comprehensive compliance audits are performed at least every three years, while some specific programs (e.g. operating procedures, lockout/tagout, etc.) are reviewed annually by the RMPC or his designees.  One of the key points of the RMP is ensuring that actual written procedures are implemented.  The audit process evaluates whether written procedures are actually implemented.  The level of detail in the audit will vary depending upon the operation.  The results of the audit are documented and incorporated into the facility RMP Plan. 



1.12    INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

The facility investigates every incident that results in, or could have reasonably resulted in, a catastrophic release of highly hazardous chemicals within 48 hours of the incident.  We recommend that all accidents be investigated.  The standard investigation system for evaluating these types of accidents is included in Section 12.0 or the RMP.  This includes an investigation form which must be completed at the time of the accident.



Upon completion of this activity, a

group of individuals investigates and determines why the accident took place.  Recommendations for corrective actions are provided, implemented, and documented.  This minimizes the potential for re-occurrence of future similar accidents.



1.13    EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

Employees are one of the key components in safety management systems.  The facility involves employees in the implementation of this plan as follows:



?    Employees are involved in safety procedure development and the PHA

?    Employees are provided periodic training through regular meetings

?    Safety meetings are held periodically and empower employees to recommend and implement corrective actions



Employee recommendations are incorporated into safety procedures.



1.14    HOT WORK PERMITS

This system provides a process whereby each heat producing work activity is evaluated and controlled to prevent fires.  Efforts are made to ensure that the entire facility completes hot work permits if the activity is outside dedicated fire protected areas (e.g. shop).  This minimizes the potential for catastrophic fires which could affect the chlorine process.  The instruction and permits can be found in Section 14.0 of the RMP.



1.15    CONTRACTORS

The facility informs contract employers of the potential hazards of the process and ensures that they are properly trained.  Before working in and around hazardous processes, these contractors are provided with the facility's safety requirements and notification forms found in Section 15.0 of the RMP.  They should also complete a safe work permit.  Safe Work Permits need to be completed during process system servicing.



1.16    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility establishes and implements a plan which deals with emergency situations at the facility to include the handling of small releases.  A standard emergency evacuation plan is available for the facility.  It should be noted that specific emergency measures can also be found in the operating procedures in Secti

on 6.0 of the RMP.

The emergency plan is practiced (e.g. drilled) on a periodic basis and its effectiveness is documented and evaluated.  The Plan is also coordinated with the LEPC and Fire Departments or HAZMAT teams.  



1.17    TRADE SECRETS

The RMP provides for protection of trade secrets incidental to the process.  The facility currently has no trade secrets which have been disclosed and, therefore, does not require compliance with this particular area of the standard.



1.18    OTHER

During the preparation of this RMP plan, a number of sources were used for reference materials throughout this document.  These included publications from the Chlorine Institute, the National Fire Protection Association, the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health and a variety of other sources.  In addition, unpublished standard operating procedures have also been adapted from a number of companies including, but not limited to, Monsanto, Dow, Occidental Chemical, King, Olin, etc.  The appropriate references for the preceding information are available upon request.



Please note that the preceding information is a general audit of the RMP requirements.  Additional specific information and requirements are provided in the RMP plan and should be reviewed and implemented accordingly.
